snippet: Anti-American unrest and an Afghan government plan to abolish private security companies have muddled the plans and projects of private aid groups, officials say.
abstract: Private aid groups in Afghanistan are facing an uncertain future as anti-American sentiment in the country grows and the Afghan government takes steps to abolish private security companies; groups, which carry out most of the American-financed development work in the country, are scrambling to sort out their operations, imperiling billions of dollars in projects that are an essential component of the Obama administration's plans for Afghanistan following military withdrawal.

byline.original: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG and GRAHAM BOWLEY
byline.contributor: Matthew Rosenberg reported from Washington, and Graham Bowley from Kabul, Afghanistan.

lead_paragraph: Anti-American unrest and an Afghan government plan to abolish private security companies have muddled the plans and projects of private aid groups, officials say.

headline.seo: Afghan Anger and Security Changes Imperil Aid Groups
headline.main: Security Fears Lead Groups to Rethink Work in Afghanistan
headline.print_headline: Afghan Anger and Security Fears Put Aid Groups’ Plans at Risk

keywords.value: United States Agency for International Development
keywords.name: organizations
